text: This is a recurring topic "_Agreed. Docs of major projects are still incomplete or non-existent, there's a lot of projects that have been nigh abandoned (cough naive bayes cough), and ..."_   perhaps we should take it more seriously.

text: The problem here is definitely not that people aren't aware of this problem, but writing good docs is really hard and package maintainers are usually already busy as-is. Julia does participate in GSoD and there are more and more packages putting lots of effort into documentation, but it's not something that will happen overnight.

text: <@UM30MT6RF> yes, I understand that package developers are usually busy as it is. However, we could have a documentathon or something like that. At least make examples on the julialang documentation and the most used packages.

text:
> The problem here is definitely not that people aren't aware of this problem, but writing good docs is really hard and package maintainers are usually already busy as-is.
I think it's a community culture thing. As a community, Julia values code more than docs. That's not an inherently good or bad thing (and I think focusing on code makes sense when you're young and exploring and growing).

But Python developers and Java developers (etc.) also only have 24 hours in the day. It's just that they (or at least, some circles) do put a premium on documentation that (most of) the Julia community does not. If you make a contribution to pandas that's not well documented, it will get rejected, no matter how clean the code is because they place a premium on documentation.

elements.text: The problem here is definitely not that people aren't aware of this problem, but writing good docs is really hard and package maintainers are usually already busy as-is.

But Python developers and Java developers (etc.) also only have 24 hours in the day. It's just that they (or at least, some circles) do put a premium on documentation that (most of) the Julia community does not. If you make a contribution to pandas that's not well documented, it will get rejected, no matter how clean the code is because they place a premium on documentation.

text: It has felt like a lot of things I have had to kind of just learn on the go, so whenever people ask me for resources on "How do I learn Julia as an R user" its hard to say much besides listing some similar packages and diving right in

elements.text: It has felt like a lot of things I have had to kind of just learn on the go, so whenever people ask me for resources on "How do I learn Julia as an R user" its hard to say much besides listing some similar packages and diving right in

text:
TL;DR; We lack _digested_ documentation that is newbie friendly.

That's the usual feedback that I get from people: _"I can't find any answers on how to do X in Stack Overflow"_, _"the official documentation is written by experts for experts"_ and _"I can't find any documentation of PackageA so I can't use it"._ Personally I have found that many packages refer to external references for their package so, you need to learn how to use the external package (usually for another programming language or another context like an RFC) and _then_ how to map this knowledge to the Julia package. This creates cognitive friction from people that want to (casually) start using Julia, but don't have the required knowledge to use the packages.  Let's face it, people like documentation with examples that they can copy/paste and make work now and think about it later.

text: An additional problem I’ve frequently encountered is figuring out which library to use for a problem. This could be figuring out which plotting or data manipulation package to use. In that case I may need to learn on some level two or three before deciding on the one, and learning this others was just overhead.
